metadata.title: Nano-application of a Resistance Inducer to Reduce Phytophthora Disease in Pineapple (Ananas comosus L.)

sections.text:
Nano-application of a Resistance Inducer to Reduce Phytophthora Disease in Pineapple (Ananas comosus L.)
XINHUA LU1, DEQUAN SUN1*, James E. Rookes2, Lingxue Kong3, Xiumei Zhang1, David
Cahill2*
1South Subtropical Crops Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Tropical Agricultural
Sciences, China, 2School of Life and Environmental Sciences, Deakin University,
Australia, 3Institute for Frontier Materials, Deakin University, Australia
Submitted to Journal: Frontiers in Plant Science
Specialty Section: Plant Microbe Interactions
ISSN: 1664-462X
Article type: Original Research Article
Received on: 24 Apr 2019
Accepted on: 05 Sep 2019
Provisional PDF published on: 05 Sep 2019
Frontiers website link: www.frontiersin.org
Citation: Lu X, Sun D, Rookes JE, Kong L, Zhang X and Cahill D(2019) Nano-application of a Resistance Inducer to Reduce Phytophthora Disease in Pineapple (Ananas comosus L.). Front. Plant Sci. 10:1238. doi:10.3389/fpls.2019.01238

Pro i siona
l
Frontiers in Plant Science | www.frontiersin.org
Provi siona
l
1 Nano-application of a Resistance Inducer to Reduce1 Phytophthora Disease in Pineapple (Ananas comosus L.)2 Xinhua Lu1,2, Dequan Sun1,*, James E. Rookes2, Lingxue Kong3, Xiumei Zhang1,3 David M. Cahill2,*4 1 Key Laboratory of Tropical Fruit Biology, Ministry of Agriculture, South Subtropical Crop5 Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Tropical Agricultural Science, Zhanjiang 524091,6 China, 2Deakin University, School of Life and Environmental Sciences, Geelong Campus at7 Waurn Ponds, Victoria 3216, Australia, 3Deakin University, Institute for Frontier Materials,8 Geelong Campus at Waurn Ponds, Victoria 3216, Australia9 10 * Corresponding author11 Dequan Sun12 sscrisun@163.com13 David M. Cahill14 david.cahill@deakin.edu.au15 16 Treatment of plants with a variety of abiotic and biotic inducers causes induced resistance to17 pathogen attack. In this study, the effect of four resistance inducers on plant diseases caused18 by Phytophthora cinnamomi was screened in vivo initially by using lupin, a susceptible19 model plant. Lupin pretreated with 0.5 mM salicylic acid (SA) showed effective resistance20 against P. cinnamomi with restricted lesions. Then, mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs)21 with particle size around 20 nm and approximate pore size of 3.0 nm were synthesized and22 functionalized for loading and importing SA to pineapple plantlets. Decanethiol gatekeepers23 were introduced to the surface of MSNs via glutathione (GSH)-cleavable disulfide linkages to24 cover the pore entrance, which was confirmed through using Raman spectroscopy. Through25 free diffusion, the loading efficiency of SA in MSNs gated with gatekeepers was 11.7 %, but26 was lower in MSNs without gatekeepers (8.0 %). In addition, in vitro release profile of SA27 from gatekeeper capped MSNs indicated that higher concentrations of GSH resulted in more28 cargo release. Moreover, the experiments in planta showed that, the application of MSNs as a29 resistance inducer delivery system significantly improved pineapple resistance to P.30 cinnamomi in terms of inhibiting lesion development and improving root growth of infected31 plants, compared to the use of free SA and MSNs without gatekeepers. The analysis of SA,32 GSH and defense-related genes of PR1 and PR5 further confirmed the slow and prolonged33 release of SA from MSNs inside the roots of pineapple plants was achieved through a redox-34 stimuli release mechanism. Therefore, the application of MSNs with redox-responsive35 gatekeepers has shown great potential as an efficient tool for delivering chemicals into plants36 in a controllable way.37 38 Keywords: mesoporous silica nanoparticles, resistance inducers, salicylic acid,39 gatekeeper, Phytophthora, pineapple40 41 INTRODUCTION42 Phytophthora cinnamomi, a plant pathogen with a world-wide distribution, infects thousands43 of plant species, including trees, woody shrubs and herbs (Allardyce et al., 2012; Cahill et al.,44 2008). P. cinnamomi invades roots, grows inside the root system, and causes root rot, which45 Pr vi sion
2 impedes water uptake and transport to the shoot, finally leading to wilting and chlorosis of46 the foliage (Hardham and Blackman, 2018). The long-term survival ability of the pathogen is47 attributed to the fact that it can grow symptomlessly in infected plants or in the soil, which48 makes the complete eradication of the disease extremely difficult (Jung et al., 2013).49 Currently, P. cinnamomi causes destructive plant disease in areas with a Mediterranean50 climate, including parts of the United States, Australia, Mexico and the Iberian Peninsula51 (Burgess et al., 2017). The pathogen not only causes considerable economic losses in52 agriculture, horticulture and forestry, but also leads to disastrous consequences for53 biodiversity and natural ecosystems.54 Pineapple (Ananas comosus L.) is the third most important fruit crop in the tropical and55 subtropical regions of the world, only preceded by banana and citrus (Lu et al., 2014).56 However, heart and root rot disease of pineapple caused by P. cinnamomi results in serious57 losses and greatly limits the development of pineapple industry in a number of countries58 (Anderson et al., 2012). Compared to other crops, pineapple leaf and canopy transpiration59 rates are very low. The accumulation of water in the top soil easily happens, especially when60 the plantlets are planted in high density, leading to a conducive environment for61 Phytophthora infections. Moreover, new roots of pineapple are highly susceptible to root62 pathogens such as P. cinnamomi (Rohrbach and Johnson, 2003). Currently, there is no63 effective method available to eradicate P. cinnamomi without destroying the infected plants.64 Most of the current control measures aim to reduce the spread of the pathogen and to improve65 plant defense via cultural or chemical methods (Gunning et al., 2013). Approaches to66 alleviate the damage of P. cinnamomi in pineapple include growing the plants in aerated67 raised and well drained beds, and supplementing soil with elemental sulphur which reduces68 the soil pH below 3.8. However, sulphur may cause adverse effects on plant nutrition as the69 low pH value inhibits the absorption of important nutrient elements such as potassium,70 magnesium and calcium (Anderson et al., 2012).71 Studies have shown that the exogenous application of a number of compounds that act as72 resistance inducers or ‘primers’, may induce plant defense including broad-spectrum73 systemic acquired resistance (SAR) or/and induced systemic resistance (ISR) to pathogen74 infection (Walters et al., 2013). However, the effects of these resistance inducers are greatly75 limited when conventionally used since a large amount of the chemicals cannot be introduced76 into crops due to the low uptake rate and high cost. Moreover, resistance inducers tend to be77 decomposed or removed by climatic factors under complex environmental conditions before78 they are absorbed into crops (Mukhopadhyay, 2014). Recently, the rapid development of79 nanotechnology has offered new methods to address these issues. Among all the engineered80 nanoparticles (ENPs), mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) are especially attractive as a81 novel biomolecule carrier because of their unique properties. The application of MSNs as a82 controlled drug delivery system to import anticancer drugs into various mammalian cells and83 tissues has been widely reported (Freitas et al., 2017; Khosravian et al., 2018; Li et al., 2016).84 However, the utilization of MSNs to transport agrochemicals is still at the initial stage. In one85 study, MSNs were applied for the encapsulation of 2,4-D sodium salt. The controlled release86 of the herbicide was achieved and MSN-based system greatly reduced the soil leaching of the87 entrapped chemical (Cao et al., 2017). Recently, MSNs were employed to transport the88 phytohormone abscisic acid (ABA), and the release of the imported ABA was provided in the89 model plant of Arabidopsis thaliana (Sun et al., 2018). However, until now the application of90 MSNs as a controlled delivery vehicle for importing resistance inducers to control plant91 disease is still to be reported.92 In this study, four resistance inducers, salicylic acid (SA), methyl jasmonate (MeJA),93 phosphite (Phi), and DL-β-amino-butyric acid (BABA), were screened in lupin plants94 following inoculation with P. cinnamomi. Monodispersed MSNs with a particle and pore size95 Pr vi sio a l
3 of approximately 20 nm and 3.0 nm respectively, were synthesized and functionalized. To96 achieve the aim of controlled release of the entrapped cargoes, the concept of gatekeepers97 was applied. Decanethiol gatekeepers were modified to the surface of MSNs via GSH-98 cleavable disulfide linkages. The loading efficiency of SA and in vitro release pattern in the99 presence of different levels of glutathione (GSH) was determined. Finally, SA was imported100 into pineapple plantlets using MSN-mediated delivery system with redox-responsive101 gatekeepers. The efficiency of this novel delivery system for the control of plant disease102 caused by P. cinnamomi was evaluated through the analysis of different parameters related to103 the infected root growth and development. In addition, the contents of SA and GSH in the104 tested plants were measured. The expression of pathogen defense related genes of PR1 and105 PR5 in the treated roots was also examined and qualified. We herein report that the MSN-106 mediated delivery system with redox-responsive gatekeepers greatly enhances the ability of107 resistance inducers to control plant disease. Hence, the study demonstrates the potential108 application of MSNs in agriculture.109 MATERIALSAND METHODS110 Growth and maintenance of experimental plants111 Lupin [Lupinus angustifolius var. Wonga] seeds were purchased from Greenpatch Organic112 Seeds (Taree, New South Wales, Australia). Firstly, lupin seeds were submerged in distilled113 water for 5 h, then sterilized for 2 min with sodium hypochlorite (1%, v/v) , followed by114 rinsing with tap water for 5 min to remove extra disinfectant. Next, the seeds were placed in a115 tray on multi-layer of paper towel, which was moistened with distilled water. The tray was116 then covered with aluminum foil and incubated at 22 °C in the dark. After 2 d, germinated117 seeds with a uniform radical length of about 0.5 cm were selected for placing in a soil-free118 plant growth system according to Gunning and Cahill (2009). Nutrient solution (Total119 Horticultural Concentrate; Excel Distributors, Reservoir, Australia) was applied once a week120 following the manufacturer’s recommendations. Lupin plantlets were transferred into a121 growth cabinet (Thermoline, Coburg North, Australia) at 22 °C with 16/8 h photoperiod with122 light intensity of 250-300 μmol m-2s-1.123 plantlets of pineapple (Ananas comosus cv. ‘MD-2’) were propagated using a leaf-bud124 cutting method (Seow and Wee, 1970). Pineapple crowns were kindly provided by Mr. Col125 Scott (Tropical Pines Pty Ltd., Queensland, Australia). In general, an active bud may grow126 into a pineapple plantlet because the photosynthesizing leaf attached to the bud provides the127 bud with nutrition. The pineapple propagation method using leaf-buds is presented in128 Supplementary Figure S1. A single leaf with an axillary bud (leaf-bud) at the base was129 carefully dissected from the pineapple crowns. The leaf-bud cuttings were submerged in a130 0.1% potassium permanganate solution for 1 h. Then the cuttings were rinsed by tap water for131 at least 5 min and allowed to air dry. The cuttings were then planted in pots with sterilized132 medium (sand: peat, 50:50). They were kept in the growth cabinet, maintaining temperature133 at 25 °C with 16/8 h photoperiod at 250-300 μmol m-2s-1. Water was sprayed every other day134 and 500 mL water was added into the container twice each week to keep the growth medium135 wet. In addition, nutrient solution was applied once a week. The buds developed into plantlets136 in 2-3 months post planting (MPP). After the plantlets grew to about 6 cm height, they were137 carefully detached from the joint leaves and transplanted into soil (Debco® Premium potting138 mix, Debco, Victoria, Australia), with 1 plant per pot (6 cm diameter), then were returned to139 the above growth conditions. Water and nutrient solution were supplied regularly. At 3.5-4140 MPP, the plantlets about 10 cm in length were removed from soil and rinsed with tap water.141 All the primary roots were cut. Finally, the plantlets without roots were transferred into the142 soil-free plant growth system to develop new clean roots for pathogen inoculation.143 Pr vi o
4 P. cinnamomi preparation144 The P. cinnamomi A2 isolate DU046 was from the Deakin University culture collection. The145 isolate was maintained on 10 % clarified V8-juice (CV) agar medium at 24 °C in the dark and146 subcultured every 7 d. Zoospores of P. cinnamomi were obtained according to the method of147 Byrt and Grant (1979). The density of zoospores was counted using a hemocytometer and148 inoculations were performed at 1×105 spores/mL.149 Resistance inducer screening on P. cinnamomi infection of lupin roots150 The activities of resistance inducers were investigated by using lupin, a susceptible model151 species to P. cinnamomi. The resistance inducers tested in the study were SA, MeJA, Phi and152 BABA. In this study, ‘Throw Down’ systemic fungicide was purchased as the source of Phi153 (YaraNipro Pty Ltd, Queensland, Australia), with the active content of 400 g/L phosphorous154 acid (H3PO3), presenting as mono (KH2PO3) and di-potassium phosphite (K2HPO3). Different155 concentrations of SA (0.1, 0.5, 1.0, 5 mM), MeJA (0.1, 1.0, 10, 100 µM), Phi (0.01, 0.1, 1, 10156 g/L) and BABA (0.01, 0.1, 1, 10 g/L) were prepared using sterile distilled water (sdH2O). For157 SA and MeJA, they were dissolved in a small volume of absolute ethanol first, then added158 with sdH2O to the desired concentration.159 Five-day-old lupin plantlets were sprayed with the four inducers using a hand spray bottle160 (10 mL), with three sprays for both sides of each leaf. As a control, sdH2O was directly161 sprayed to the plants. After 2 d, each root was inoculated with a 20 µL drop of P. cinnamomi162 zoospore suspension (1 × 105 spores/mL), placed 5 mm behind the root tip. Each experiment163 included three biological replicates. A replicate consisted of 12 lupin plantlets. Untreated164 plants were included as a control treatment. At 6 day post inoculation (dpi), root growth and165 lesion length were recorded, along with the incidence of disease, and the number of lateral166 roots formed. Disease severity was graded from 0 to 5 according to lesion length: 0, no167 visible symptoms; 1, mild, lesion length on ˂20% of the root length; 2, mild to moderate,168 lesion length on 20-30 % of the root length; 3, moderate, lesion length on 30-40% of the root169 length; 4, moderate to severe, lesion length on 40-50% of the root length; 5, severe, lesion170 length on >50% of the root length.171 Synthesis of MSNs as a controlled agrochemical delivery system172 The synthesis and modification of MSNs before loading resistance inducers were conducted173 according to the previous methods (Sun et al., 2018; Yi et al., 2015). To link redox-174 responsive short-chain gatekeepers, thiol groups were first introduced at the pore entrance of175 the particles which contain the template of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) inside.176 Typically, 200 mg of MSNs were suspended in 200 mL of ethanol, followed by adding 0.2177 mL of (3-Mercaptopropyl) trimethoxysilane (MPTMS) into the mixture dropwise under178 stirring. After 1 h, two milliliter of Milli-Q water was added and the resulting solution was179 stirred 24 h at room temperature. Subsequently, the solution was heated to 80 ºC to stabilize180 the silanol groups between MSNs and MPTMS. The resulting powder was collected by181 centrifugation at 8000 g for 10 min, then was washed with ethanol. The as-prepared particles182 were resuspended in a solution containing 100 mL of ethanol and 1 mL of hydrochloric acid183 (32%), under vigorous stirring and heated at 60 ºC for 12 h. The final thiol group184 functionalized MSNs without CTAB template were obtained after centrifugation, washing185 and drying. It was designated as MSN+SH.186 According to resistance inducer screening, SA was employed as a loaded and imported187 cargo. The cargo loading procedure was performed through a free diffusion method. Briefly,188 200 mg of SA was dissolved in 10 mL of absolute ethyl acetate (EA). Then 200 mg of189 MSN+SH was added in the SA-EA mixture solution. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min190 and kept in a rotating shaker at room temperature for 24 h, so that the SA molecules entered191 into the pores completely through free diffusion. A blank containing MSN+SH in EA was192 Pr vi si a l
5 also prepared. Afterwards, 0.5 mL of didecyl disulfide was added into the above mixture to193 react with the thiol groups to produce the 'disulphide bridge' gatekeepers. The reaction was194 continued at the same condition for another 24 h. Then the excessive SA and EA were195 removed by centrifugation and repeated washing with 40% (v/v) ethanol. Subsequently, the196 resulting particles were quickly frozen in liquid nitrogen to keep the cargos inside the197 mesopores and then dried in a freeze dryer for 36 h. The SA-loaded MSNs with gatekeepers198 were designated as MSN+SA+G. As a control, MSNs without gatekeepers were used to load199 SA and the sample was designated as MSN+SA.200 Characterization201 The morphology of MSNs after modification was observed by transmission electron202 microscope (TEM, JEM-2100 electron microscope, JEOL, Japan) with an accelerating203 voltage of 200 kV. Surface changes and porosity of the NPs were analyzed by nitrogen204 adsorption-desorption isotherms analysis (Micromeritics Tristar 3000 Analyzer, Particle and205 Surface Science, UK) at -196 ºC under a static adsorption condition. The surface area and206 pore volume were calculated by the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller and Barrett−Joyner−Halenda207 (BET/BJH) analysis (Brunauer et al., 1938; Barrett et al., 1951), and the pore size208 distributions were obtained by the BJH method. Raman spectra were checked by using a209 Raman microscopy (Renishaw, United Kingdom) with laser wavelength of 514 nm, equipped210 with a confocal microscope.211 MSN molecular loading and in vitro release212 To determine the loading efficiency (LE) and loading capacity (LC) of SA, the amount of SA in213 the supernatant during the loading procedure was measured with a UV-Visible214 spectrophotometer (Cary 300; Agilent, United States) at a wavelength of 305 nm. The LE and215 LC of SA in the NPs was calculated as follows: LE (%) = (weight of SA loaded in NPs /216 Total amount of SA added) × 100%，LC (µg/mg)= weight of SA loaded in NPs/SA-loaded NPs.217 The resistance inducer in vitro release was carried out using a dialysis method. Firstly,218 bare MSNs or gatekeeper-capped MSNs with SA (3 mg) were placed in a dialysis tubing219 (Sigma; MWCO 2,000 Da, St. Louis, Missouri, USA), which was wrapped by a steel mesh to220 hold it on the top of a cuvette. Then the wrapped NPs were immersed in 3.5 mL water or221 different concentrations of GSH (1, 5 and 10 mM). At predetermined time intervals, 0.2 mL222 of the solution was collected in order to measure the released SA, and then the fresh223 corresponding release solution was immediately replenished to maintain the same total224 solution volume. SA in the solution was quantified to monitor the release. The cumulative225 molecule release was calculated according to the following equation:226 Amount of SA released (µg) = Vs i=0 n−1 Ci + V0Cn227 where Vs is the sampled volume collected at a predetermined time interval (Vs = 0.2 mL); Ci228 (µg/mL) is the SA concentration released in the solution at time i; V0 is the volume of release229 solution (V0=3.5 mL); and n is the number of samples. For each resistance inducer the230 measurements were carried out three biological replicates.231 Exposure of pineapple to SA, MSNs, andMSN+SA+G232 Prior to delivery to plants, SA was dissolved in a small volume of absolute ethanol, and then233 sdH2O was added to obtain the desired concentration. MSNs and MSN+SA+G were234 dispersed in sdH2O and sonicated for at least 2 h to form a homogeneous suspension. Based235 on previous experiment, the abaxial and adaxial leaf surfaces of pineapple plantlets were236 sprayed until runoff with free SA (0.5 mM), MSNs (0.5 mg/mL) or MSN+SA+G (0.5 mg/mL)237 containing 0.5 mM SA, respectively, using a hand spray bottle. Control samples were238 Pr vi i al
6 conducted with an equivalent amount of sdH2O. After being sprayed, plantlets were allowed239 to dry and then returned into the growth cabinet. After 3 d, root tips of pineapple plantlets240 were inoculated with a 20 µL drop of P. cinnamomi zoospore suspension (1×105 spores/mL)241 or water (mock inoculation). The experimental design and pineapple plantlets were treated as242 follows: non-inoculated control, water treated/ mock inoculation (W-P); inoculated control,243 water treated/P. cinnamomi inoculated (W+P); SA treated/mock inoculation (SA-P); SA244 treated/P. cinnamomi inoculated (SA+P); bare MSN treated/mock inoculation (MSNs-P);245 bare MSN treated/P. cinnamomi inoculated (MSNs+P); MSN+SA+G treated/mock246 inoculation (MSN+SA+G-P); and MSN+SA+G treated/P. cinnamomi inoculated247 (MSN+SA+G+P). Each experiment included three biological replicates. A replicate consisted248 of 10 pineapple plantlets and about 2~3 roots were treated per plantlet. Root samples were249 collected at the designated time point for direct use, or frozen immediately in liquid nitrogen250 and stored at -80 ºC for further analysis.251 Assessment of root growth and lesion development in inoculated pineapple plants252 After incubation, the plants were checked for root growth and visible lesions every 2 d until 6253 dpi. Percentages of lesion length to root length in controls and pathogen inoculated plants254 were assessed, along with quantification of lateral root formation.255 Quantification of SA and GSH in pineapple roots inoculated with P. cinnamomi256 The content of SA transported into roots was determined using a high performance liquid257 chromatography (HPLC) (Agilent technologies, California, USA) according to Pan et al.258 (2010) with minor modification. Briefly, approximately 100 mg of roots from each of 3259 plants per treatment was frozen in liquid nitrogen in a 1.7 mL Eppendorf tube, and ground to260 a fine powder. One milliliter of extraction buffer [2-propanol/H2O/concentrated HCl261 (2/1/0.002, V/V/V)] was added. The mixture was vortexed at a speed of 100 rpm for 30 min.262 Then 2 mL of dichloromethane was added into the mixture and incubated for another 30 m in263 the shaker at a speed of 100 rpm. Afterwards samples were centrifuged at 13,000 g for 10264 min and 900 µL of the cleared liquid from the lower phase were carefully removed and265 placed into a fresh tube. The liquid was then air dried using a nitrogen evaporator. Finally,266 the samples were re-dissolved in 0.1 mL of 20% methanol and filtered through a 0.45 µm267 syringe filter and stored at -80 ºC until analysis. Fifty microliter of each sample was injected268 into the column for analysis. The concentration of SA was determined according to a269 standard curve from SA calibration standards.270 In plant cells, glutathione exists in reduced and oxidized forms. In this study, the total271 glutathione (GSH+GSSG) in pineapple roots was used to assess the oxidative stress after272 pathogen inoculation. The GSH content was determined using a Glutathione Assay kit273 (Sigma).The sample was first deproteinized with the 5% 5-sulfosalicylic acid solution. GSH274 content of the sample was then assayed using a kinetic assay in which catalytic amounts of275 glutathione cause a continuous reduction of 5,5 -dithiobis-(2-nitrobenzoic) acid (DTNB) to276 TNB. In brief, roots (100 mg) from each of 3 plants per treatment were frozen in liquid277 nitrogen in a 1.7 mL Eppendorf tube, and then ground to a fine powder. One millilitre of278 chilled 6% meta-phosphoric acid was added, the suspension vortexed vigorously and then279 centrifuged at 14,000 g for 20 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was transferred into a fresh tube280 and kept on ice in the dark. The total GSH in the supernatant was quantified according to the281 manufacturer’s protocols. The fluorescent product was measured at 412 nm using a282 microplate reader (Thermo Scientific Variokan, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) and GSH283 content was determined using a GSH standard curve.284 Resistance-related gene expression analysis in pineapple roots inoculated with P.285 cinnamomi286 Pr i sio l
7 Resistance-related gene expression was analyzed by semi-quantitative reverse transcription287 polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) in pineapple roots inoculated with P. cinnamomi. In288 brief, total RNA was extracted from 100 mg of pineapple root samples using Trizol (TRI289 Reagent®, Sigma). For cDNA synthesis, a Tetro cDNA synthesis kit (Bioline, Alexandria,290 NSW, Australia) was used according to manufacturer’s instructions. DNA sequences of291 pathogenesis related gene of PR1 and PR5 in pineapple were kindly provided by Dr. Lubing292 Zhang from Chinese Academy of Tropical Agricultural Sciences (China). Primers were293 designed using Primer3 version 0.4.0 and listed in Table 1. RT-PCR was conducted to294 evaluate the relative expression of PR1 and PR5 with Go Taq ® green master mix (Promega,295 Madison, WI, USA). Briefly, PCR reactions contained 10 μL GoTaq, 8 μL DEPC treated296 water, 0.5 μL F primer, 0.5 μL R Primer and 1 μL cDNA. PCR conditions consisted of an297 initial denaturing step of 3 min at 95°C, followed by 31 cycles for PR1, 36 cycles for PR5,298 and 35 cycles for Actin, at 95°C for 30 sec, 62°C for 30 sec and 72°C for 30 sec. The299 resulting PCR was run on a 1.8 % agarose gel stained with EtBr and visualised under UV.300 Gene band intensity in the gels was measured by using Image J software, and quantification301 for relative gene expression was estimated against the reference gene (Actin).302 Statistical Analysis303 All experiments in this study were conducted with three biological replicates. Data are304 presented as mean ± standard deviation (SD). Statistical analysis was performed on the305 differences between the controls (CK) and treatments by using Duncan’s multiple range test306 at p < 0.05 (one asterisk) with IBM SPSS 24.0 software.307 RESULTS308 Morphology and physico-chemical properties of MSNs309 The size and shape of MSNs did not change significantly after being functionalized with thiol310 groups (Figure 1)，and the mesoporous structure inside the MSNs could be clearly observed311 from the image. The particle mesoporosity was also confirmed by nitrogen sorption isotherms312 (Supplementary Figure S2) and BET/BJH method (Supplementary Table S1). The Raman313 spectra showed the characteristics of MSNs capped with gatekeepers (Figure 2). The314 absorption peak for disulfide bonds was observed between 500 and 550 cm-1 in the spectrum.315 After capping the gatekeepers, the peak around 2600 cm-1 was still present in MSNs, which316 corresponded to thiol groups of didecyl disulfide. In addition, the increased intensity of -CH2-317 /-CH3 peaks between 2800 and 3000 cm-1 could be attributable to introduction of the alkyl318 chain from decanethiol.319 Screening resistance inducers on lupin inoculated with P. cinnamomi320 As shown in Supplementary Figure S3, no symptoms were observed for non-inoculated321 control lupin. Inoculated control roots exhibited the most serious disease symptoms which322 were present as water-soaked, discoloured, long spreading lesions. Among the four resistance323 inducers (Supplementary Figure S3 and Table S2), SA proved to be the most effective324 against P. cinnamomi and promoted root growth at the concentration of 0.5 and 1.0 mM after325 inoculation, showing restricted infection with more lateral root formation.326 SA loading and release327 In this study, the LE of SA was 8.0 % and 11.7 % for the bare MSNs and gatekeeper-capped328 MSNs, respectively (Supplementary Table S3). So, about 88.8 and 134.1 µg SA /mg were329 loaded into MSN+SA and MSN+SA+G, which suggested that gatekeepers could block the330 pore entrance and prevent guest molecules from premature release.331 In the absence of GSH, SA was released quickly from MSN+SA and reached 27.9 % at332 24h (Figure 3A). In contrast, MSN+SA+G released only a small amount of SA at the333 Provi si a l
8 beginning, then reaching a maximum value at 10 h (4.0 %). However, as shown in Figure 3B,334 the leakage of SA from gatekeeper capped MSNs exhibited a fast ‘initial burst’ leakage in the335 first 1h (14.8 % and 26.6 %, respectively) in the presence of a high concentration of GSH (5,336 10 mM), and this was followed by a continuous release until 24 h (37.9 % and 39.2 %,337 respectively). In comparison, the SA release was characterized by a similar burst release in338 the first 1 h (9.6 %) but was relatively slow at a low GSH concentration (1mM).339 Symptom development in P. cinnamomi inoculated pineapple roots pre-exposed to SA,340 MSNs or MSN+SA+G341 As shown in Figure 4, roots in all inoculated treatments responded to the pathogen infection,342 and produced lesions. At 6 dpi, the inoculated control (W+P) possessed the most severe343 symptoms with water-soaked, brown, spreading, long lesions commencing at the root tip,344 with few lateral roots. Roots in the SA+P treatment exhibited similar symptoms, but with345 shorter lesions and longer lateral roots compared with the inoculated control. However,346 MSNs+P and MSN+SA+G+P treatments showed restricted lesions and lateral roots were347 stimulated. In addition, for the MSN+SA+G+P treatment, the roots recovered and continued348 to grow.349 The average root growth at 2 d post inoculation in all pineapple plants is shown in350 Supplementary Figure S4. Compared to the other treatments, the MSNs-P and351 MSN+SA+G-P treatments had significantly enhanced root growth over 6 d. However, W+P352 significantly inhibited the root growth compared with non-inoculated control (W-P). At 4 dpi353 and 6 dpi, the root growth of all the pathogen inoculated plants were impeded, compared with354 the controls.355 The lesion lengths caused by P. cinnamomi in pineapple roots were recorded every 2 d356 post inoculation until 6 dpi (Figure 5A). The results showed that SA, MSNs and357 MSN+SA+G significantly reduced lesion length at all time points. In addition, the358 MSN+SA+G+P treatment showed a significant reduction in lesion length compared with the359 other treatments over time. Compared to the W+P treatment, the percentage of lesion length360 to root length also significantly decreased in the plants treated by SA, MSNs and361 MSN+SA+G at varying time points (Figure 5B). Moreover, lesions in MSNs and362 MSN+SA+G treated plants were observed as restricted infection, and in some MSN+SA+G363 treated plants, the infection sites were difficult to observe.364 SA and GSH quantification after pathogen inoculation365 As shown in Figure 6A, the content of SA in control roots remained at a low level for the366 duration of the experiment. But after pathogen inoculation, the SA level in the W+P367 treatment significantly increased at 24 hpi, then dropped to the original level. By 24 hpi, the368 SA content in the SA-P treatment significantly decreased, while in the SA+P, MSNs-P,369 MSNs+P, MSN+SA+G+P and MSN+SA+G-P treatments SA continued to increase.370 Moreover, it was found that the contents of SA in MSN+SA+G pretreated roots were371 elevated over the time, and the MSN+SA+G+P treatment significantly improved the SA level372 in the roots compared with the MSN+SA+G-P treatment at 48 hpi and 96 hpi.373 It was found that, by 0 hpi, the GSH levels were increased 1.5 fold under MSNs-P, 1.4374 fold under MSNs+P, 1.7 fold under MSN+SA+G-P, and 2.0 fold under MSN+SA+G+P375 treatment compared with W-P (Figure 6B). In addition, a considerable increase from 0-24376 hpi was observed in the plants treated with MSNs+P and then the level slightly declined at 48377 hpi, remaining the highest GSH content compared to all the other treatments except for the378 treatment group of MSN+SA+G+P. In the roots exposed to the treatment of MSN+SA+G+P,379 a continuous increase in GSH content was observed throughout the experiment and a380 significantly higher level was found at each the time-point compared to that in all the other381 treatments.382 Provi sio a l
9 Resistance-related gene expression analysis in pineapple roots inoculated with P.383 cinnamomi384 As shown in Figure 7A, expression of PR1 in the tissue treated with W+P increased at 12385 and 24 hpi, and then gradually declined to the same level in W-P treatment at 96 hpi. SA+P386 significantly elevated PR1 expression at 0 hpi, and about 5.0 times, 3.5 times and 2.0 times387 higher expression were observed compared to the treatments of W-P, W+P and SA-P,388 respectively. After that, PR1 demonstrated a continuous decrease in expression until 96 hpi.389 The treatment of MSNs-P increased the expression of PR1 and the highest level was detected390 at 0 hpi. Later on, PR1 expression remained at a high level with slight variation for all the391 subsequent time-points. In the roots exposed to the treatment of MSNs+P, the highest level of392 gene expression was achieved at 6 hpi and then the level gradually declined. A considerably393 elevated PR1 expression was observed in the roots treated with MSN+SA+G+P and the394 expression levels were obviously higher than that in all the other treatments at all time-points.395 The overall pattern of PR5 expression was similar to that of PR1 expression. PR5396 expression levels were greatly increased in the roots exposed to the treatment of397 MSN+SA+G+P than that in all the other treatments at all time-points. The highest value was398 observed at 6 hpi, then PR5 expression slowly decreased but was still maintained above the399 control level until 96 hpi (Figure 7B).400 DISCUSSION401 It is well recognized that treatment of plants with various biotic and abiotic agents can result402 in the induction of both local and systematic resistance to subsequent pathogen attack403 (Palmer et al., 2017). In the present study, in comparison to the other resistance inducers404 screened, SA at 0.5-5.0 mM was found to be more effective in limiting lesion development in405 lupin caused by P. cinnamomi, reduced disease severity and promoted root growth. A406 previous study showed that the exposure of avocado roots to SA , for example, induced the407 accumulation of compounds which effectively induced resistance to P. cinnamomi (Rangel-408 Sánchez et al., 2014). As a result, SA was taken further to analyze the potential of MSNs as a409 vehicle for delivering a resistance inducing agent to pineapple, the main aim of this study.410 MSNs with specifically localized functionalization are essential for maintaining the411 particle size and pore volume. The results from BET/BJH method showed that the surface of412 MSN+SH significantly decreased because of their occupation by thiol groups. The pore413 volume and pore diameter of MSN+SH did not reduce dramatically, providing effective414 loading capacity for hosting a guest molecule. Previous research has demonstrated that the415 size of MSNs could impact on their uptake into plants, and further affect the efficacy of the416 delivery system (Sun et al., 2014). After being loaded with SA, the pore volume of MSNs417 decreased dramatically, which meant the pores were occupied. The absorption peak between418 500 and 550 cm-1 in the spectrum of the didecyl disulfide revealed the covalent disulfide419 bonds, which were generated after oxidation of decanethiol (Gosselin et al., 2007).420 High LE of resistance inducers into MSNs is critical for further applications in plants.421 Studies have indicated that LE was directly related to the mesoporous structure, pore size,422 surface area and surface modification of MSNs (Cao et al., 2016). The results presented in the423 current study showed that the LE of SA was nearly 1.5 times higher than that of the bare424 MSNs. The improved loading capacity was due to the capping of the pores by the gatekeeper425 molecules which blocked the loss of SA and limited premature leakage. The in vitro redox-426 responsive release test demonstrated that the release of SA from decanethiol gatekeeper427 covered MSNs slowed down considerably compared to that of MSNs without gatekeepers.428 Further, the release rate of the entrapped SA improved with the increase in the levels of GSH429 stimulus.430 Pr vi si l
10
Resistance inducer carriers with controllable release in response to environmental stimuli431 are extremely critical for improving the efficiency of loaded molecules. In this study, the432 disulfide-linked gatekeeper capped MSNs comprise the mesopores of MSNs as a reservoir for433 resistance inducers, the disulfide bond as a redox-responsive cleavable linker, and the434 decanethiol “gatekeeper” that can cover the entrance of MSNs. Here, the concentrations of435 GSH played a critical role in determining the SA release rate. The higher concentrations of436 GSH quickly cleaved the disulfide bonds between decanethiol and MSNs, opening the space437 for the release of SA. Thus, the gatekeeper capped MSNs could be a potential delivery438 system in that resistance inducers can be encapsulated without being prematurely released439 until the gatekeeper is removed by GSH which accumulates to high concentrations in plants440 under stress conditions (Agarwal, 2007; Arasimowicz et al., 2014; Zechmann, 2014).441 More interestingly, MSN treatments exhibited a significant improvement in all root442 growth. These beneficial effects are mainly attributed to silica, the major component of silica443 nanoparticles (SNPs), which play important roles in enhancing plant growth and improving444 plant resistance (Li et al., 2012; Sun et al., 2016; Suriyaprabha et al., 2014a; Yuvakkumar et445 al., 2011). In addition, MSNs alone evidently reduced lesion development. Previous studies446 have shown that SNPs could increase the resistance of plants to various biotic and abiotic447 stresses such as salinity in bean (Phaseolus vulgaris) (Alsaeedi et al., 2017), UV-B stress in448 wheat (Triticum aestivum) seedlings (Tripathi et al., 2017) and fungal attack in maize449 (Suriyaprabha et al., 2014b), which might have protected plants via triggering plant defense system,450 enhancing antioxidants and phenolic compounds, alleviating reactive oxygen species-induced damage451 to photosynthesis. Moreover, MSNs treatment induced the accumulation of SA in the treated452 roots. This might be attributed to the silica elements from MSNs which could stimulate the453 biosynthesis of the stress hormones such as SA, JA and ET in the treated plants (Fauteux et454 al., 2006).455 Studies have shown that the exogenous application of SA can trigger SAR against a wide456 range of pathogens that cause disease in many plant species (Faize and Faize, 2018). In the457 present study, a constant increase and high level of SA in the tissue exposed to the treatments458 with the application of the MSN-mediated delivery system was observed. So, a sustained459 release of entrapped SA from the mesopores was achieved, thus improving the plant’s overall460 resistance ability. It is recognized that during interactions with pathogens, GSH is not only461 involved in signaling roles but related to hormone and secondary metabolite synthesis. In462 general, a certain level of GSH is needed for the synthesis of pathogen defense-related463 molecules and disease resistance (Ghanta and Chattopadhyay, 2011). In the present study, in464 the roots exposed to SA encapsulated in MSNs, the GSH level was higher than all the other465 treated groups during all experiments and continuously increased until the end of the test. The466 exogenous use of SA may also enhance GSH level in treated plants, indicating a467 physiological interaction between GSH and SA levels (Freeman et al., 2005; Mateo et al.,468 2006). Hence, the changes in GSH levels in the treated roots further confirmed the success of469 this MSN-mediated delivery system for the controlled release of SA.470 The syntheses of pathogenesis proteins PR1 and PR5 are an example of inducible defence471 mechanisms that plants can trigger to resist pathogen invasion, and their expression has been472 directly correlated with the developmental transition to resistance (Ponciano et al., 2006;473 Engelbrecht and van den Berg, 2013). In the current study, the application of SA and MSNs474 elevated the transcription of PR1 and PR5 both in infected and non-infected roots. In addition,475 a similar result was observed in the expression of PR5 except that free SA introduced a476 significant higher expression at the beginning and the peak of PR5 level occurred at 12 h. The477 sustained and elevated expression of PR1 and PR5 was attributed to a constant supply of SA478 released from the pores of the MSNs. Similar to these results, a recent study showed the479 expression of the ABA-induced gene AtGALK2 in Arabidopsis was prolonged due to the480 P ovi ion l
11
application of MSN-mediated ABA delivery system (Sun et al., 2018). Together, in the481 present study, PR1 and PR5 gene expression levels, and SA and GSH quantification482 demonstrated that the MSN-mediated delivery system provided a sustained release of SA to483 plants, offering prolonged protection against pathogen attack.484
CONCLUSION485
The MSN-mediated delivery system with short-chain molecules gated as redox-responsive486 gatekeepers was synthesized and applied for the control of plant disease. The in vitro release487 experiments indicated that decanethiol gatekeepers effectively blocked the loaded SA inside488 MSNs without the presence of GSH. However, the disulfide bonds between decanethiol and489 MSNs were cleaved with the presence of GSH, resulting in the release of entrapped SA.490 Further, in planta experiments demonstrated that the controlled release of SA from491 decanethiol gated MSNs induced sustained expression of the plant defense genes PR1 and492 PR5 and improved pineapple plantlet resistance to root rot disease caused by P. cinnamomi.493 Hence, in the present study, the application of MSNs with redox-responsive gatekeepers has494 been demonstrated to be an efficient technique to introduce resistance inducers into plants495 and release them in a controllable fashion.496
AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS497
XL, LK and DC proposed and designed the experiments. XL carried out experiments. XL and498 DS analyzed data and wrote the paper. JR and DC revised the manuscript. XZ helped in499 finalizing the manuscript and secured funding. All authors read and approved the final500 manuscript.501

referenceMentions.context: Phytophthora cinnamomi, a plant pathogen with a world-wide distribution, infects thousands 43 of plant species, including trees, woody shrubs and herbs (Allardyce et al., 2012; Cahill et al., 44 2008).

The long-term survival ability of the pathogen is 47 attributed to the fact that it can grow symptomlessly in infected plants or in the soil, which 48 makes the complete eradication of the disease extremely difficult (Jung et al., 2013).

71 Studies have shown that the exogenous application of a number of compounds that act as 72 resistance inducers or ‘primers’, may induce plant defense including broad-spectrum 73 systemic acquired resistance (SAR) or/and induced systemic resistance (ISR) to pathogen 74 infection (Walters et al., 2013).
Moreover, resistance inducers tend to be 77 decomposed or removed by climatic factors under complex environmental conditions before 78 they are absorbed into crops (Mukhopadhyay, 2014).

It is well recognized that treatment of plants with various biotic and abiotic agents can result 402 in the induction of both local and systematic resistance to subsequent pathogen attack 403 (Palmer et al., 2017).
